subjects.subject: Physics
subjects.textbook: Physics – Textbook for Class XI (Part I & II)

chapters.title: Physical World
topics: What is physics and its scope

notes.summary: Introduces physics as a study of nature, its vast scope from sub-atomic to cosmic scales, and the role of physical laws in technology and society.
key_points: Physics explains natural phenomena using a small set of fundamental laws.
Applications of physics drive technological development, which in turn impacts society.
Physical laws are universal, expressed mathematically, and are based on experimental evidence.

notes.summary: Covers standard units, measurement techniques, error types, and dimensional analysis as tools to check and derive physical relations.
key_points: Physical quantities are expressed as a numerical value and a unit, preferably from the SI system.
Measurements are affected by systematic and random errors, so results are reported with significant figures.
Dimensional analysis helps verify equations and obtain relations between physical quantities approximately.

chapters.title: Motion in a Straight Line
topics: Average and instantaneous velocity and speed

notes.summary: Describes one-dimensional motion using displacement, velocity, and acceleration, and represents motion through graphs.
key_points: Distance is a scalar path length while displacement is a vector joining initial and final positions.
Velocity is the rate of change of displacement; speed is the rate of change of distance.
Graphs of position–time and velocity–time are powerful tools to visualise and analyse motion.

notes.summary: Extends motion to two dimensions using vectors, explaining projectiles and circular motion.
key_points: Vectors have both magnitude and direction and follow rules of vector addition and resolution.
Projectile motion is analysed as independent horizontal and vertical motions under gravity.
Uniform circular motion involves constant speed but continuously changing velocity due to centripetal acceleration.

notes.summary: Presents Newton’s laws that relate forces to motion, introducing inertia, momentum, and their conservation.
key_points: First law defines inertia and conditions for uniform motion or rest.
Second law relates net force to rate of change of momentum and gives F = ma for constant mass.
Third law explains mutual forces between interacting bodies and underlies conservation of momentum.

chapters.title: Work, Energy and Power
topics: Work done by constant and variable forces

notes.summary: Connects force and motion to work and energy, and introduces power as the rate of doing work.
key_points: Work is non-zero when a component of force acts along the displacement.
Kinetic energy depends on speed; potential energy depends on configuration or position in a field.
Total mechanical energy is conserved in absence of non-conservative forces like friction.

chapters.title: System of Particles and Rotational Motion
topics: Moment of inertia and rotational dynamics

notes.summary: Extends mechanics to systems of particles and rotating rigid bodies using torque, angular momentum, and moment of inertia.
key_points: Centre of mass describes the average position of mass of a system and follows Newton’s laws.
Torque is the rotational analogue of force and causes change in angular momentum.
Rotational motion obeys equations similar to linear motion, with moment of inertia playing the role of mass.

notes.summary: Describes gravitational attraction between masses, free fall, and motion of planets and satellites.
key_points: Gravitational force is attractive, acts between any two masses, and decreases with square of distance.
Acceleration due to gravity near Earth is approximately constant but varies with height and depth.
Satellites move in orbits due to balance between gravitational pull and their tangential velocity.

notes.summary: Explains how solids deform under external forces and introduces stress–strain relations and elastic constants.
key_points: Stress is force per unit area; strain is fractional change in dimension.
Within elastic limit, stress is proportional to strain (Hooke’s law).
Different moduli quantify resistance to stretching, compression, and shearing.

notes.summary: Covers how fluids exert pressure, cause buoyant forces, and show resistance to flow and surface phenomena.
key_points: Fluid pressure increases with depth and acts equally in all directions at a point.
Archimedes’ principle explains buoyancy and conditions for floating and sinking.
Viscosity measures internal friction in liquids and gases; surface tension governs droplet and capillary behaviour.

chapters.title: Thermal Properties of Matter
topics: Change of state and latent heat

notes.summary: Relates heat transfer to changes in temperature, size, and state of matter.
key_points: Temperature measures degree of hotness; heat is energy in transit due to temperature difference.
Different materials have different specific heat capacities, affecting how they warm up or cool down.
Thermal expansion of solids, liquids, and gases has many engineering and everyday applications.

chapters.title: Thermodynamics
topics: Zeroth, first, and second laws of thermodynamics (basic level)

notes.summary: Introduces the laws of thermodynamics governing heat, work, and internal energy in macroscopic systems.
key_points: The zeroth law defines thermal equilibrium and underlies the concept of temperature.
The first law is a statement of energy conservation including heat and work transfers.
The second law introduces directionality in processes and explains why some processes are irreversible.

chapters.title: Kinetic Theory
topics: Kinetic theory of an ideal gas
Pressure of a gas and molecular motion

notes.summary: Explains macroscopic properties of gases using microscopic motion of particles.
key_points: Gases are composed of molecules in constant random motion obeying simple postulates.
Pressure arises from molecular collisions with container walls.
Average kinetic energy of gas molecules is directly proportional to absolute temperature.

notes.summary: Describes periodic motions with emphasis on simple harmonic motion and its energy changes.
key_points: Oscillatory motion repeats itself about an equilibrium position after fixed time intervals.
In SHM, restoring force is proportional to displacement and directed towards equilibrium.
Kinetic and potential energies interchange during SHM while total energy remains constant.

chapters.title: Waves
topics: Types of waves: transverse and longitudinal
Sound waves and basics of beats and Doppler (qualitative)

notes.summary: Introduces mechanical waves, their characteristics, and basic ideas of sound propagation.
key_points: Waves transfer energy without overall transfer of matter.
Wave speed is related to frequency and wavelength by a simple relation.
Superposition of waves explains interference patterns and phenomena like beats.

subjects.subject: Chemistry
subjects.textbook: Chemistry – Textbook for Class XI (Part I & II)

notes.summary: Builds the quantitative foundation of chemistry using mole concept, stoichiometry, and basic laws.
key_points: Matter is described using atoms, molecules, and moles for convenient counting.
Laws of chemical combination support the idea of definite and multiple proportions.
Stoichiometry relates masses, moles, and volumes of reactants and products in reactions.

notes.summary: Traces development of atomic models and introduces quantum description of electrons in atoms.
key_points: Experimental evidence led from indivisible atoms to a model with electrons, protons, and neutrons.
Bohr’s model explained hydrogen spectrum but failed for multi-electron atoms.
Quantum numbers and orbitals describe probable locations and energies of electrons.

chapters.title: Classification of Elements and Periodicity in Properties
topics: Modern periodic law and long form periodic table
Trends in atomic and ionic size, ionisation enthalpy, electronegativity

notes.summary: Explains the basis of the periodic table and trends in elemental properties across periods and groups.
key_points: Periodic properties are periodic functions of atomic number.
Trends in size, ionisation enthalpy, electron gain enthalpy, and electronegativity help predict reactivity.
Position of an element in the table reflects its valence shell configuration and chemical behaviour.

notes.summary: Discusses how atoms combine to form molecules, predicting bond types and shapes from electronic structure.
key_points: Chemical bonds result from electrostatic attraction or sharing of electrons.
Lewis structures visualise valence electrons and help predict simple molecular shapes.
VSEPR model and hybridisation explain real three-dimensional geometries and bond angles.

chapters.title: States of Matter: Gases and Liquids
topics: Gas laws and ideal gas equation
Liquid state: properties related to intermolecular forces

notes.summary: Links microscopic interactions to macroscopic behaviour of gases and liquids.
key_points: Gas behaviour is described by relationships between pressure, volume, temperature, and moles.
Ideal gas equation combines simple gas laws into one relation.
Deviation from ideality and properties of liquids arise from intermolecular attractions.

chapters.title: Thermodynamics
topics: System, surroundings, and types of systems

notes.summary: Deals with energy changes in chemical and physical processes using thermodynamic concepts.
key_points: Internal energy and enthalpy track heat and work exchange in processes at different conditions.
The first law enforces conservation of energy in all processes.
Spontaneity depends on both enthalpy and entropy changes of the system.

chapters.title: Equilibrium
topics: Ionic equilibrium: strong and weak electrolytes, pH (basic level)

notes.summary: Explains physical and chemical equilibria, equilibrium constants, and response to change in conditions.
key_points: At equilibrium, forward and reverse reaction rates are equal though molecules keep reacting.
Equilibrium constants indicate the extent of reaction under given conditions.
Le Chatelier’s principle predicts how equilibrium shifts to counter imposed changes.

chapters.title: Redox Reactions
topics: Oxidation–reduction in terms of oxygen, hydrogen, and electrons

notes.summary: Covers oxidation–reduction concepts and identifies redox processes in chemical and biological systems.
key_points: Redox reactions involve simultaneous oxidation and reduction processes.
Oxidation states help track electron transfer in complex molecules and ions.
Many industrial, biological, and environmental processes are fundamentally redox in nature.

chapters.title: Hydrogen
topics: Position of hydrogen in periodic table
Water and hydrogen peroxide (basic properties and uses)

notes.summary: Focuses on hydrogen’s unique position and its compounds, including water and hydrogen peroxide.
key_points: Hydrogen resembles both alkali metals and halogens but forms its own category.
Different hydrides show varying bonding and properties depending on the partner element.
Water and hydrogen peroxide play central roles in chemistry, environment, and industry.

chapters.title: The s-Block Elements
topics: General trends in Group 1 and 2 elements
Important compounds: NaCl, NaOH, CaO, CaCO3 (etc.)

notes.summary: Describes alkali and alkaline earth metals, their trends, and key compounds.
key_points: s-Block elements are highly reactive metals with characteristic flame colours and soft textures.
Their oxides and hydroxides are basic and widely used in industry.
Sodium, potassium, calcium, and magnesium ions are crucial in biological systems.

chapters.title: The p-Block Elements (Group 13 and 14)
topics: Important compounds of boron, aluminium, carbon, and silicon

notes.summary: Covers trends in Groups 13 and 14 with emphasis on boron, aluminium, carbon, and silicon chemistry.
key_points: p-Block elements show variable oxidation states and covalent bonding.
Boron and carbon display anomalous behaviour compared to heavier group members.
Carbon’s allotropes and silicon-based materials underpin modern materials science.

chapters.title: Organic Chemistry – Some Basic Principles and Techniques
topics: Classification and nomenclature of organic compounds
Methods of purification of organic compounds

notes.summary: Lays foundations of organic chemistry language, structure, and purification methods.
key_points: Systematic IUPAC rules name organic compounds based on parent chain, substituents, and functional groups.
Electron-distribution effects help explain reactivity patterns in organic molecules.
Organic compounds are purified by distillation, crystallisation, chromatography, and related techniques.

chapters.title: Hydrocarbons
topics: Alkanes, alkenes, and alkynes: preparation and properties

notes.summary: Deals with the major classes of hydrocarbons and their typical reactions.
key_points: Hydrocarbons differ in saturation and structure, leading to substitution, addition, and aromatic reactions.
Benzene and related compounds have special stability and substitution chemistry.
Hydrocarbons are primary fuels and feedstocks but must be managed responsibly due to pollution concerns.

chapters.title: Environmental Chemistry
topics: Pollution of air, water, and soil (overview)
Chemical nature and effects of common pollutants

notes.summary: Introduces chemical aspects of environmental issues and basic concepts of green chemistry.
key_points: Industrial and domestic activities release pollutants affecting air, water, and soil quality.
Understanding chemical behaviour of pollutants helps design control and remediation strategies.
Green chemistry aims to design processes that minimise hazardous substances and waste.

notes.summary: Introduces features of living organisms and the need for scientific classification and naming.
key_points: Living systems show organisation, metabolism, growth, reproduction, and response to stimuli.
Huge diversity of life is organised using taxonomic categories like species, genus, and family.
Binomial nomenclature gives each species a unique, universally accepted scientific name.

chapters.title: Biological Classification
topics: Five-kingdom concept (Monera, Protista, Fungi, Plantae, Animalia)

notes.summary: Describes major groups of organisms and criteria used to classify them.
key_points: Classification reflects evolutionary relationships and simplifies study of organisms.
Kingdoms differ in cell type, body organisation, mode of nutrition, and reproduction.
Viruses are acellular entities requiring host cells for replication.

notes.summary: Covers major plant groups and broad patterns in their structure and reproduction.
key_points: Plant groups show increasing complexity from simple algae to flowering plants.
Life cycles alternate between haploid gametophyte and diploid sporophyte phases.
Each group occupies specific ecological niches and has economic importance.

chapters.title: Animal Kingdom
topics: Chordate groups up to class level

notes.summary: Introduces animal diversity and classification based on body organisation and key features.
key_points: Animals are grouped by body symmetry, germ layers, coelom type, and segmentation.
Non-chordates range from simple sponges to arthropods and molluscs.
Chordates share notochord, dorsal nerve cord, and are divided into major vertebrate classes.

chapters.title: Morphology of Flowering Plants
topics: Root, stem, leaf: types and modifications

notes.summary: Describes external features and modifications of angiosperms with common examples.
key_points: Roots, stems, and leaves show structural variations suited to support, storage, and reproduction.
Flower parts are organised in whorls and may be used to identify plant families.
Fruits and seeds protect and help disperse the next generation.

chapters.title: Anatomy of Flowering Plants
topics: Tissues in roots, stems, and leaves
Differences in dicot and monocot structures

notes.summary: Looks at internal structure of plant organs and patterns of tissue organisation.
key_points: Dermal, ground, and vascular tissues are arranged in characteristic ways in organs.
Secondary growth increases girth through activity of lateral meristems.
Dicots and monocots differ in vascular bundle arrangement and root–stem anatomy.

chapters.title: Structural Organisation in Animals
topics: Morphology and anatomy of representatives (e.g., earthworm, cockroach, frog) – overview

notes.summary: Explores how animal cells form tissues and organs in representative organisms.
key_points: Different tissues specialise in protection, support, movement, and coordination.
Simple animals show basic organ systems that become more complex in higher forms.
Study of standard organisms provides models for understanding body organisation.

notes.summary: Reinforces the idea of the cell as the basic unit and surveys structures shared across life.
key_points: All living organisms are built from one or more cells.
Prokaryotic cells lack membrane-bound organelles; eukaryotic cells possess them.
Organelles like nucleus, mitochondria, and chloroplasts coordinate cell functions.

chapters.title: Biomolecules
topics: Carbohydrates, proteins, lipids, nucleic acids (basic structures and roles)

notes.summary: Introduces major classes of biological molecules and how enzymes catalyse life’s reactions.
key_points: Biomolecules form the structural and functional basis of cells.
Proteins perform diverse tasks from catalysis to transport and signalling.
Enzymes lower activation energy and are highly specific for substrates.

chapters.title: Cell Cycle and Cell Division
topics: Meiosis and its role in sexual reproduction

notes.summary: Explains how cells divide for growth and reproduction, and how meiosis creates variation.
key_points: The cell cycle alternates between growth (interphase) and division.
Mitosis produces genetically identical daughter cells for growth and repair.
Meiosis reduces chromosome number by half and generates genetic diversity.

chapters.title: Transport in Plants
topics: Water movement: root pressure, transpiration pull

notes.summary: Describes mechanisms by which water and nutrients move through plant bodies.
key_points: Water enters roots by osmosis and moves upwards through xylem.
Transpiration from leaves helps pull water up the plant column.
Phloem transports sugars from sources to sinks by pressure flow.

notes.summary: Covers mineral requirements of plants and basic nitrogen assimilation.
key_points: Plants require macro and micro-nutrients for normal growth.
Deficiencies cause characteristic visual symptoms in leaves and stems.
Nitrogen is made available through biological and industrial fixation pathways.

notes.summary: Explains how plants convert light energy into chemical energy in chloroplasts.
key_points: Chlorophyll pigments capture light in chloroplast membranes.
Light reactions produce ATP and NADPH; dark reactions fix CO2 using these.
Different pathways allow plants to adapt to varied environmental conditions.

notes.summary: Shows how plants break down food molecules to release usable energy.
key_points: Cellular respiration oxidises organic substrates to produce ATP.
Different stages occur in cytoplasm and mitochondria.
Aerobic pathways yield more energy than anaerobic routes.

notes.summary: Describes how plants grow and respond to internal hormones and external cues.
key_points: Growth involves cell division, enlargement, and differentiation.
Plant hormones coordinate processes like elongation, branching, and senescence.
Environmental signals like light duration can trigger flowering or dormancy.

notes.summary: Explains how humans process food into absorbable units and utilise nutrients.
key_points: Digestive tract organs perform mechanical and chemical breakdown of food.
Enzymes act on carbohydrates, proteins, and lipids in successive regions.
Absorbed nutrients are transported and used for energy, growth, and repair.

chapters.title: Breathing and Exchange of Gases
topics: Transport of oxygen and carbon dioxide

notes.summary: Covers structures and processes ensuring gas exchange for cellular respiration.
key_points: Air passages and lungs provide large surface area for gas exchange.
Breathing is driven by pressure changes from diaphragm and intercostal muscle activity.
Oxygen and carbon dioxide are transported mainly bound to haemoglobin or dissolved in plasma.

chapters.title: Body Fluids and Circulation
topics: Structure and working of the heart

notes.summary: Explains transport of substances in humans through blood, heart, and vessels.
key_points: Blood contains cells and plasma carrying gases, nutrients, and wastes.
The heart pumps blood through pulmonary and systemic circuits.
Homeostatic mechanisms maintain pressure and composition within safe limits.

notes.summary: Describes how the body removes nitrogenous and other wastes to maintain internal balance.
key_points: Kidneys filter blood and regulate water and salt balance.
Nephrons perform filtration, reabsorption, and secretion steps.
Hormonal control adjusts urine volume and concentration.

notes.summary: Explores how the musculoskeletal system enables body movements.
key_points: Skeletal muscles attach to bones and work in antagonistic pairs.
Bones and joints provide leverage and support for movement.
Muscle fibres contract through sliding of protein filaments using ATP.

notes.summary: Shows how the nervous system rapidly coordinates body functions.
key_points: Neurons carry electrical impulses along axons and between synapses.
Brain and spinal cord integrate sensory inputs and produce responses.
Reflex arcs provide quick protective reactions without full conscious control.

chapters.title: Chemical Coordination and Integration
topics: Major human hormones and their roles

notes.summary: Explains hormonal control of slower, long-term processes complementing nervous control.
key_points: Endocrine glands secrete hormones directly into blood without ducts.
Hormones regulate growth, metabolism, reproduction, and stress responses.
Feedback loops maintain hormone levels within narrow ranges.
